awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Topological Planning in Information Space for Intelligent Robotic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project envisions mobile robotic systems capable of retrieving streaming information about any physical location in the world for the benefit of scientists, first responders, and the general public. In the past decade, a number of marine and aerial systems have emerged in applications such as environmental monitoring, search and rescue, surveillance, and scientific exploration. However, currently an operator either teleoperates these vehicles directly or pre-specifies waypoint locations in a fixed plan. These approaches lead to severely limited performance by restricting the capabilities of robotic vehicles to (1) continue operating effectively as their environment, mission, and teammates change and (2) incorporate high-level goals given by human operators. This project seeks to bridge the gap between current systems that naively follow waypoints and intelligent systems capable of adapting to their environment, their team's capabilities, and to the goals of the operator. 

The ultimate objective of this project is to develop topological planning techniques based on homotopy and persistent homology that reason over a compact semantic representation of environmental conditions (e.g., informative areas, disturbances, and risky areas). By reasoning over concise semantic maps, the proposed methods will enable teams of autonomous vehicles to make decisions regarding information collection, cost minimization, and goal achievement in the physical world. The developed algorithms will be made publicly available through open source distribution and transitioned to field tests through ongoing collaborations with ocean scientists. The educational component of this project will integrate robotic vehicle planning into the graduate curriculum at Oregon State University through a Marine Robotics Certificate program and into Oregon high schools through an underwater robot programming module designed by the Oregon State University undergraduate Robotics Club.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project improved planning for robotic systems in scientific data collection applications by introducing the concept of a topological information space with explainable semantic maps. The robotics research community has recently seen significant advances in techniques that operate under physical constraints, but existing techniques were insufficient to tackle information gathering objectives in large-scale field robotics applications. This project provided the necessary fundamental research contributions to enable efficient and adaptive autonomy for marine, aerial, and ground systems in unstructured outdoor environments. 

This project showed that planning in a topological information space is beneficial in the problem domains of underground exploration, underwater information gathering, and geological sampling. The results showed that utilizing semantic concepts leads to more explainable path planning methods that are interpretable to humans. The project also showed that intelligently learning user preferences and providing explainable decisions leads to improved performance for data collection with robotic systems, specifically in field deployments for geological sampling and oceanographic monitoring. These initial applications serve as a proof of concept towards a principled and generalizable framework for robot planning in information space.

This project moves us towards a system that allows scientists, first responders, and the public to retrieve information about the world through streaming data from mobile robotic vehicles. The developed algorithms were made publicly available through open-source distribution and transitioned to field tests with scientists through ongoing collaborations with the Hatfield Marine Science Center, Pacific Marine Energy Center, ASSURE FAA Center of Excellence for Unmanned Systems, and the Oregon State University College of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences. Over the course of this project, the team collaborated with geologists and oceanographers to field the proposed system. The team completed a 10-day sea trial off the coast of Louisiana and a geological survey on Mt. Hood, Oregon to test the system. These real-world field trials and collaborations have improved data collection in oceanography and geology.

One undergraduate summer researcher, two high school interns, and four graduate students (three PhD and one MS) have been supported on this project. Research from this grant formed the basis for the MS and PhD theses produced by the graduate students. The graduate students helped develop and deploy a high school underwater robotics module, which is currently in use by 30+ students per year, giving a cohort of high school students experience with robotic systems. The robotics module will continue to be reused in subsequent years to increase impact. Finally, the Oregon State University Robotics Club participated in prototype development for the high school module, and they will take this experiential learning experience with them after graduation.

Themes from this project were integrated into a graduate-level Sequential Decision Making in Robotics class. Incorporating state-of-the-art research in topological planning helped prepare approximately 40 PhD/MS students in this class (taught every two years) to better understand robotics research related to motion planning and decision making. Lastly, the data and tools from this project were made available to the public through distribution on the principal investigator's GitHub website.


Last Modified: 03/20/2025
Modified by: Geoffrey A Hollinger
